SCHEDULE 5.01

Permitted Encumbrances
(To Be Updated Post Closing)

United States and Canadian Permitted Encumbrances
 
1.
General
 
None.
 
2.           Goderich, Ontario
 
 
a.
Easement Agreement dated June 26, 1995 between The Corporation of the Town of Goderich and Sifto Canada Corp., registered August 2, 1996, Instr. # R310881, (Sifto Canada Corp. gets salt rights and grants easements for sewers).
 
 
b.
Easement Agreement dated June 26, 1995 between The Corporation of the Town of Goderich and Sifto Canada Corp., registered August 2, 1996, Instr. # R310880.
 
 
c.
Easement Agreement dated August 8, 2005 between Sifto Canada Corp. and Epcor Power Development Corporation.
 
 
d.
Agreement between The Corporation of the Town of Goderich and Sifto Canada Corp. dated June 26, 1995 for easements for storm sewers and salt registered August 2, 1996 instrument #R310881.
 
 
e.
Industrial Siding Agreement between Canadian National Railway Company and Domtar Chemicals Limited - Sifto Salt Division.
 
 
f.
Agreement dated 6/94 between Sifto Canada Corp. and Menesetung Bridge Association Inc. and Maitland Trail Association whereby Sifto Canada Corp. grants license to use pathway on premises for pedestrian use.
 
 
g.
Agreement among Sifto Canada Corp., Goderich Port Management Corporation and the Corporation of the Town of Goderich dated as of November 11, 1999 pursuant to which the Town of Goderich has certain rights of first refusal over Sifto parcel pursuant to the terms thereof, an agreement/notice of which may be registered.
 
 
h.
Subject to the extension of Maitland Road through parts of Lots 1 and 2, as opened by By-Law No. 4 of 1874 dated May 6, 1874 as outlined on Plan 454.
 
 
i.
Reservation in favor of the Corporation of the Township of Huron, its successors and assigns of the right of ingress and egress and the right to remove gravel and sand from a portion of the lands on part of the property as contained in Instrument No. 30994.
 
 
j.
An easement in favour of the Hydro Electric Power Commission over Lot 3 in the First Concession, Western Division, Township of Colborne, County of Huron, more particularly described in Instrument No. 8195.
 
 
k.
The responses from the municipality of the Township of Colborne received in 1990 indicate that a portion of the parcel located on Lot 2 in the First Concession, Western Division, Township of Colborne, County of Huron is zoned to permit the use of land for magazines.  The same responses indicate that a portion of the parcel located on Lot 3 in the First Concession, Western Division, Township of Colborne, County of Huron is zoned as a natural environment zone.  While magazines used to be located on the lands zoned as a natural environment, these lands are no longer used for magazines.

 
5.01 - 1
 
 
  SCHEDULE 5.01
 
 
l.
A caution registered as Instrument No. LT011758 against that portion of the lands which is in the land titles system of registration, and a deposit registered as Instrument No. 0341502 against that portion of the lands registered in the land registry system of registration.
 
 
m.
Those exceptions set out in Schedule B of Title Insurance Policy No. ONL0024259 issued by First America Title Insurance Company dated November 28, 2001.

EXHIBIT A-1

Form of Term Note

TERM NOTE

$_______________
New York, New York   
________________, __________   

FOR VALUE RECEIVED, COMPASS MINERALS GROUP, INC., a Delaware corporation (the “US Borrower”), hereby promises to pay to __________ or its registered assigns (the “Lender”), in lawful money of the United States of America in immediately available funds, at the applicable Notice/Payment Office (as defined in the Credit Agreement referred to below) on the Term Loan Maturity Date (as defined in the Credit Agreement) the principal sum of ____________ DOLLARS ($____________) or, if less, the unpaid principal amount of all Term Loans (as defined in the Credit Agreement) made by the Lender pursuant to the Credit Agreement.

The US Borrower also promises to pay interest on the unpaid principal amount hereof in like money at said office from the date hereof until paid at the rates and at the times provided in Section 2.14 of the Credit Agreement.

This Note is one of the Term Notes referred to in the Credit Agreement, dated as of November 28, 2001, as amended and restated as of April 10, 2002, as further amended and restated as of December 22, 2005, among Compass Minerals International, Inc. (formerly known as Salt Holdings Corporation), the US Borrower, Sifto Canada Corp., a company incorporated under the laws of the province of Ontario, Canada, Salt Union Limited, a company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, the lending institutions from time to time party thereto (including the Lender) and JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as Administrative Agent (as amended, restated, modified, waived and/or supplemented from time to time, the “Credit Agreement”), and is entitled to the benefits thereof and of the other Credit Documents (as defined and provided for in the Credit Agreement).  This Note is secured by certain of the Security Documents (as defined in the Credit Agreement) and is entitled to the benefits of certain of the Guaranties (as defined in the Credit Agreement).  This Note is subject to voluntary prepayment and mandatory repayment prior to the Term Loan Maturity Date, in whole or in part, as provided in the Credit Agreement.

In case an Event of Default (as defined in the Credit Agreement) shall occur and be continuing, the principal of and accrued interest on this Note may be declared to be due and payable in the manner and with the effect provided in the Credit Agreement.

The US Borrower hereby waives presentment, demand, protest or notice of any kind in connection with this Note.

THIS NOTE SHALL BE CONSTRUED IN ACCORDANCE WITH AND BE GOVERNED BY THE LAW OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK.


COMPASS MINERALS GROUP, INC.

$ ____________
New York, New York   
________________, __________   

FOR VALUE RECEIVED, COMPASS MINERALS GROUP, INC., a Delaware corporation (the “US Borrower”), hereby promises to pay to or its registered assigns (the “Lender”), in lawful money of the United States of America in immediately available funds, at the applicable Notice/Payment Office (as defined in the Credit Agreement) on the Revolving Loan Maturity Date (as defined in the Credit Agreement) the principal sum of ____________ DOLLARS ($____________) or, if less, the unpaid principal amount of all Revolving Loans (as defined in the Credit Agreement) made by the Lender pursuant to the Credit Agreement.

The US Borrower also promises to pay interest on the unpaid principal amount hereof in like money at said office from the date hereof until paid at the rates and at the times provided in Section 2.14 of the Credit Agreement.

This Note is one of the Revolving Notes referred to in the Credit Agreement, dated as of November 28, 2001, as amended and restated as of April 10, 2002, as further amended and restated as of December 22, 2005, among Compass Minerals International, Inc. (formerly known as Salt Holdings Corporation), the US Borrower, Sifto Canada Corp., a company incorporated under the laws of the province of Ontario, Canada, Salt Union Limited, a company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, the lending institutions from time to time party thereto (including the Lender), JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as Administrative Agent (as amended, restated, modified, waived and/or supplemented from time to time, the “Credit Agreement”), and is entitled to the benefits thereof and of the other Credit Documents (as defined in the Credit Agreement).  This Note is secured by certain of the Security Documents (as defined in the Credit Agreement) and is entitled to the benefits of certain of the Guaranties (as defined in the Credit Agreement).  This Note is subject to voluntary prepayment and mandatory repayment prior to the Revolving Loan Maturity Date, in whole or in part, as provided in the Credit Agreement.

In case an Event of Default (as defined in the Credit Agreement) shall occur and be continuing, the principal of and accrued interest on this Note may be declared to be due and payable in the manner and with the effect provided in the Credit Agreement.

The US Borrower hereby waives presentment, demand, protest or notice of any kind in connection with this Note.

EXHIBIT A-2B


Form of Global Revolving Note

GLOBAL REVOLVING NOTE

$ ____________
New York, New York   
________________, __________   

FOR VALUE RECEIVED, COMPASS MINERALS GROUP, INC., a Delaware corporation (the “US Borrower”), SIFTO CANADA CORP., a company incorporated under the laws of the province of Ontario, Canada (the “Canadian Borrower”), and SALT UNION LIMITED, a company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales (the “UK Borrower” and, together with the US Borrower and the Canadian Borrower, the “Borrowers”), hereby promise to pay to ____________ or its registered assigns (or its Canadian Lending Office or UK Lending Office, as applicable) (the “Lender”), in lawful money of the United States of America (or, as provided below, Canada or the United Kingdom) in immediately available funds, at the applicable Notice/Payment Office (as defined in the Credit Agreement), (a) on the Revolving Loan Maturity Date (as defined in the Credit Agreement), in the case of each Borrower, the unpaid principal amount of all Global Revolving Loans (as defined in the Credit Agreement) made by the Lender to such Borrower, and the unpaid face amount of all B/As of such Borrower accepted by such Lender, in each case pursuant to the Credit Agreement, and (b) as provided in Section 2.07 of the Credit Agreement, the face amount of each B/A of such Borrower accepted by such Lender, provided that, notwithstanding the fact that the principal amount of this Note is denominated in US Dollars, to the extent provided in the Credit Agreement, all payments hereunder in respect of Global Revolving Loans (other than US Dollar Loans) or B/As (each as defined in the Credit Agreement) evidenced hereby shall be made in the currency in which such Global Revolving Loans or B/As are denominated (although payments in respect of Global Revolving Loans or B/As shall be made in US Dollars (using the US Dollar Equivalent (as defined in the Credit Agreement) of such Global Revolving Loans) to the extent required pursuant to the provisions of Section 2.21 of the Credit Agreement), whether or not the US Dollar Equivalent thereof, when added to the outstanding principal amount of all US Dollar Loans (as defined in the Credit Agreement) evidenced hereby, would exceed the stated principal amount of this Note.

Each of the US Borrower, the Canadian Borrower and the UK Borrower also promises to pay interest on the unpaid principal amount hereof owed by such Borrower in like money at said office from the date hereof until paid at the rates and at the times provided in Section 2.14 of the Credit Agreement.

This Note is one of the Revolving Notes referred to in the Credit Agreement, dated as of November 28, 2001, as amended and restated as of April 10, 2002, as further amended and restated as of December 22, 2005, among Compass Minerals International, Inc. (formerly known as Salt Holdings Corporation), the US Borrower, the Canadian Borrower, the UK Borrower, the lending institutions from time to time party thereto (including the Lender) and JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as Administrative Agent (as amended, restated, modified, waived and/or supplemented from time to time, the “Credit Agreement”), and is entitled to the benefits thereof and of the other Credit Documents (as defined in the Credit Agreement).  The obligations of the US Borrower represented by this Note are secured by certain of the Security Documents (as defined in the Credit Agreement) and are entitled to the benefits of certain of the Guaranties (as defined in the Credit Agreement) and the obligations of the Canadian Borrower and the UK Borrower represented by this Note are secured by each of the Security Documents and are entitled to the benefits of each of the Guaranties.  This Note is subject to voluntary prepayment and mandatory repayment prior to the Revolving Loan Maturity Date, in whole or in part, as provided in the Credit Agreement.

In case an Event of Default (as defined in the Credit Agreement) shall occur and be continuing, the principal of and accrued interest on this Note may be declared to be due and payable in the manner and with the effect provided in the Credit Agreement.

Each of the US Borrower, the Canadian Borrower and the UK Borrower hereby waives presentment, demand, protest or notice of any kind in connection with this Note.

SWINGLINE NOTE

$ ____________
New York, New York   
________________, __________   

FOR VALUE RECEIVED, COMPASS MINERALS GROUP, INC., a Delaware corporation (the “US Borrower”), hereby promises to pay to JPMORGAN CHASE BANK,

N.A., or its registered assigns (the “Lender”), in lawful money of the United States of America in immediately available funds, at the applicable Notice/Payment Office (as defined in the Credit Agreement referred to below) on the Swingline Expiry Date (as defined in the Credit Agreement) the principal sum of FIFTEEN MILLION DOLLARS ($15,000,000) or, if less, the unpaid principal amount of all Swingline Loans (as defined in the Credit Agreement) made by the Lenders pursuant to the Credit Agreement.

The US Borrower promises to pay interest on the unpaid principal amount hereof in like money at said office from the date hereof until paid at the rates and at the times provided in Section 2.14 of the Credit Agreement.

This Note is one of the Swingline Notes referred to in the Credit Agreement, dated as of November 28, 2001, as amended and restated as of April 10, 2002, as further amended and restated as of December 22, 2005, among Compass Minerals International, Inc. (formerly known as Salt Holdings Corporation), a Delaware corporation, the US Borrower, Sifto Canada Corp., a company incorporated under the laws of the province of Ontario, Canada, Salt Union Limited, a company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, the lending institutions from time to time party thereto (including the Lender) and JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as Administrative Agent (as amended, restated, modified, waived and/or supplemented from time to time, the “Credit Agreement”), and is entitled to the benefits thereof and of the other Credit Documents (as defined in the Credit Agreement).  This Note is secured by certain of the Security Documents (as defined in the Credit Agreement) and is entitled to the benefits of certain of the Guaranties (as defined in the Credit Agreement).  This Note is subject to voluntary prepayment and mandatory repayment prior to the Swingline Expiry Date, in whole or in part, as provided in the Credit Agreement.

In case an Event of Default (as defined in the Credit Agreement) shall occur and be continuing, the principal of and accrued interest on this Note may be declared to be due and payable in the manner and with the effect provided in the Credit Agreement.

The US Borrower hereby waives presentment, demand, protest or notice of any kind in connection with this Note.

EXHIBIT B-1
Form of Opinion
 
 
[FORM OF OPINION OF LATHAM & WATKINS LLP]

Subject to the foregoing and the other matters set forth herein, as of the date hereof:

1.             Each of the Corporation Loan Parties is a corporation with corporate power and authority to enter into the Loan Documents and perform its obligations thereunder. The LLC Loan Party is a limited liability company, with limited liability company power and authority to enter into the Loan Documents and perform its obligations thereunder.  With your consent, based solely on certificates from public officials, we confirm that each of the Loan Parties is validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of Delaware.

2.             The execution, delivery and performance of the Loan Documents, the Copyright Security Agreement and the Patent and Trademark Security Agreement by each Loan Party that is a party thereto, has been duly authorized by all necessary corporate or limited liability company, as applicable, action of each Loan Party that is a party thereto and the Loan Documents, the Copyright Security Agreement and the Patent and Trademark Security have been duly executed and delivered by each Loan Party.

3.             Each of the Loan Documents constitutes a legally valid and binding obligation of each Loan Party that is a party thereto, enforceable against each Loan Party in accordance with its terms.

4.             The execution and delivery of the Loan Documents by each Loan Party, the Canadian Borrower and the UK Borrower, the borrowing of the Loans (as defined in the Credit Agreement) by the Borrowers, and the consummation by the Borrowers and the Loan Parties of the transactions contemplated by the Loan Documents, do not on the date hereof:

(i)             with respect to the Loan Parties only, violate the provisions of the Governing Documents;

(ii)            result in the breach of or a default under the 2019 Notes Indenture;

(iii)           violate any federal or New York statute, rule, or regulation applicable to such Loan Party or the DGCL or DLLCA (as applicable); or

(iv)           require any consents, approvals, or authorizations to be obtained by such Loan Party from, or any registrations, declarations or filings to be made by such Loan Party with, any governmental authority under any federal or New York statute, rule or regulation applicable to such Loan Party (including, without limitation, Regulations T, U or X of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, assuming the Borrowers comply with the provisions of the Loan Documents relating to the use of proceeds)  or the DGCL or DLLCA (as applicable) except filings and recordings required in order to perfect or otherwise protect the security interests under the US Collateral and Guaranty Agreement as amended by the USCGA Amendment (as so amended, the “Amended Collateral and Guaranty Agreement”).
 
 
 

5.             The Amended Collateral and Guaranty Agreement and together with the Reaffirmation Agreement creates a valid security interest in favor of the Collateral Agent for the benefit of the Secured Parties (as defined in the Amended Collateral and Guaranty Agreement) in that portion of the collateral described in Section 4.01 of the Amended Collateral and Guaranty Agreement in which any of the Loan Parties party thereto has rights and a valid security interest may be created under Article  9 of the New York UCC (the “UCC Collateral”), which security interest secures the Obligations (as defined in the Amended Collateral and Guaranty Agreement and as confirmed by the Reaffirmation Agreement).

6.             The Financing Statements are in appropriate form for filing in the Delaware Filing Office. Upon the proper filing of the Financing Statements in the Delaware Filing Office, the security interest in favor of the Collateral Agent for the benefit of the Lenders in each Loan Party’s rights in the UCC Collateral described in the respective Financing Statements will be perfected to the extent a security interest in such UCC Collateral can be perfected under the Delaware UCC by the filing of a financing statement in that office.

7.             Upon delivery of that portion of the UCC Collateral that constitutes “certificated securities” within the meaning of Section 8-102(a)(4) of the New York UCC (the “Pledged Securities”) to the Collateral Agent in, and while located in, the State of New York, pursuant to the Amended Collateral and Guaranty Agreement, indorsed to the Collateral Agent or in blank, in each case, by an effective endorsement, or accompanied by stock powers with respect thereto duly indorsed in blank by an effective endorsement the security interest in favor of the Collateral Agent for the benefit of the Secured Parties (as defined in the Amended Collateral and Guaranty Agreement)  in the Pledged Securities will be perfected.

8.             None of the Loan Parties is required to be registered as an “investment company” within the meaning of the Investment Company Act of 1940, as amended.

9.             Assuming that under all applicable laws of each of the parties to the Foreign Guaranty (the “Foreign Guarantors”) is validly existing, that the Foreign Guaranty and the Reaffirmation Agreement have been duly authorized, executed and delivered by the Foreign Guarantors and that the Foreign Obligations (as defined in the Foreign Guaranty) constitute legally valid and binding obligations of each Foreign Borrower (as defined in the Foreign Guaranty) under the law governing such Foreign Obligations and that such Foreign Obligations would constitute the legally valid and binding obligations of each Foreign Borrower (as defined in the Foreign Guaranty) under the law of the State of New York if New York law were applicable to such Foreign Obligations (as to which we express no opinion), the Foreign Guaranty together with the Reaffirmation Agreement constitutes a legally valid and binding obligation of each Foreign Guarantor, enforceable against each Foreign Guarantor in accordance with its terms.  We call to your attention that we have not reviewed, and are not familiar with, the Foreign Obligations.

Except as expressly set forth in paragraphs 5 through 8, we do not express any opinion with respect to the creation, validity, attachment, perfection or priority of any security interest or lien or the effectiveness of any sale or other conveyance or transfer of real or personal property.  The opinions above do not include any opinions with respect to compliance with laws relating to permissible rates of interest.
 
 
 

Our opinions are subject to:

(a)            the effects of bankruptcy, insolvency, reorganization, preference, fraudulent transfer, moratorium or other similar laws relating to or affecting the rights or remedies of creditors, and the judicial application of foreign laws or governmental actions affecting creditors’ rights;

(b)            the effects of general principles of equity, whether considered in a proceeding in equity or at law (including the possible unavailability of specific performance or injunctive relief), concepts of materiality, reasonableness, good faith, fair dealing and the discretion of the court before which a proceeding is brought;

(c)            the invalidity under certain circumstances under law or court decisions of provisions for the indemnification or exculpation of or contribution to a party with respect to a liability where such indemnification, exculpation or contribution is contrary to public policy; and

(d)            we express no opinion with respect to (i) consents to, or restrictions upon, governing law, jurisdiction, venue, service of process, arbitration, remedies or judicial relief; (ii) advance waivers of claims, defenses, rights granted by law, or notice, opportunity for hearing, evidentiary requirements, statutes of limitation, trial by jury or at law, or other procedural rights; (iii) waivers of broadly or vaguely stated rights; (iv) covenants not to compete; (v) provisions for exclusivity, election or cumulation of rights or remedies; (vi) provisions authorizing or validating conclusive or discretionary determinations; (vii) grants of setoff rights; (viii) provisions to the effect that a guarantor is liable as a primary obligor, and not as a surety and provisions purporting to waive modifications of any guaranteed obligation to the extent such modification constitutes a novation; (ix) provisions for the payment of attorneys’ fees where such payment is contrary to law or public policy; (x) proxies, powers and trusts; (xi) provisions prohibiting, restricting, or requiring consent to assignment or transfer of any right or property; (xii) provisions for liquidated damages, default interest, late charges, monetary penalties, prepayment or make-whole premiums or other economic remedies to the extent such provisions are deemed to constitute a penalty; (xiii) provisions permitting, upon acceleration of any indebtedness, collection of that portion of the stated principal amount thereof which might be determined to constitute unearned interest thereon; and (xiv) the severability, if invalid, of provisions to the foregoing effect.

We express no opinion or confirmation as to federal or state securities laws (except as set forth in paragraph 8 of this letter), tax laws, antitrust or trade regulation laws, insolvency or fraudulent transfer laws, antifraud laws, compliance with fiduciary duty requirements, pension or employee benefit laws, usury laws, environmental laws, margin regulations (except as set forth in paragraph 4(iv)), FINRA rules or stock exchange rules (without limiting other laws excluded by customary practice).
 
 
 

Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the opinions expressed above are also subject to the following limitations, exceptions and assumptions:

(a)  We have assumed that any conditions to the effectiveness of the Loan Documents have been satisfied or waived and that any required lender consents to the Loan Documents have been obtained.

(b)  We have assumed that since the original date of execution thereof, except as specifically set forth in the Amendment and the USCGA Amendment, no Existing Loan Document has been amended, restated, modified, supplemented, or terminated and that no rights pursuant thereto have been released, waived, or modified either expressly or by any action or inaction of the parties thereto and that no party has defaulted on its obligations under the Existing Loan Documents. We have assumed that immediately prior to giving effect to the Loan Documents each of the Existing Loan Documents was the legally valid, binding and enforceable obligation of the parties thereto.

(c)  We call to your attention to the fact that with respect to any collateral subject to a security interest under more than one security agreement in favor of the Collateral Agent, a court may limit the enforceability of inconsistent provisions and may limit the ability of the Collateral Agent to choose which agreement or provisions thereof to enforce.

The opinions set forth above are also subject to (i) the unenforceability of contractual provisions waiving or varying the rules listed in Section 9-602 of the New York UCC, (ii) the unenforceability under certain circumstances of contractual provisions respecting self-help or summary remedies without notice of or opportunity for hearing or correction, (iii) the effect of provisions of the New York UCC and other general legal principles that impose a duty to act in good faith and in a commercially reasonable manner, and (iv) the effect of Sections 9-406, 9-407, 9-408 and 9-409 of the New York UCC on any provision of any Loan Document that purports to prohibit, restrict, require consent for or otherwise condition the assignment of rights under such Loan Document.

We call to your attention that enforcement of a claim denominated in a foreign currency may be limited by requirements that the claim (or a judgment in respect of the claim) be converted into United States dollars, and we express no opinion as to the enforceability of any indemnity for losses associated with the exchange of the judgment currency into any other currency.

Insofar as our opinions require interpretation of the 2019 Notes Indenture, with your consent, (i) we have assumed that all courts of competent jurisdiction would enforce such agreements in accordance with their plain meaning, (ii) we express no opinion with respect to a breach or default under the Credit Agreement that would occur only upon the happening of a contingency, (iii) we express no opinion with respect to any matters which require the performance of a mathematical calculation or the making of a financial or accounting determination and (iv) we have assumed any action that requires a judgment or determination to be “reasonable” or “in good faith” has been so taken.
 
 
 

Our opinions in paragraphs 5 and 6 above are limited to Article 9 of the New York UCC, our opinions in paragraph 8 is limited to Articles 8 and 9 of the New York UCC and our opinions in paragraph 6 are limited to Article 9 of the Delaware UCC, and therefore those opinion paragraphs, among other things, do not address collateral of a type not subject to, or excluded from the coverage of, Articles 8 and 9 of the Applicable UCC.

Additionally,

(i)             We express no opinion with respect to the priority of any security interest or lien.

(ii)            We express no opinion with respect to any agricultural lien or any collateral that consists of letter-of-credit rights, commercial tort claims, goods covered by a certificate of title, claims against any government or governmental agency, consumer goods, crops growing or to be grown, timber to be cut, goods which are or are to become fixtures, or as-extracted collateral or cooperative interests.

(iii)           We assume the descriptions of Collateral (as defined in the Amended Collateral and Guaranty Agreement) contained in, or attached as schedules to, the Loan Documents and any financing statements accurately and sufficiently describe the Collateral intended to be covered by the Loan Documents or such financing statements.  Additionally, we express no opinion as to whether the phrases “all personal property” or “all assets” or similarly general phrases would be sufficient to create a valid security interest in the collateral or particular item or items of collateral; however, we note that pursuant to Section 9-504 of the New York UCC the phrases “all assets” or “all personal property” can be a sufficient description of collateral for purposes of perfection by the filing of a financing statement.

(iv)           We have assumed that each grantor of any security interest has, or with respect to after-acquired property will have, rights in the collateral granted by it or the power to transfer rights in such collateral, and that each such grantor has received value, and express no opinion as to the nature or extent of any grantor’s rights in any of the collateral and we note that with respect to any after-acquired property, the security interest will not attach until the applicable grantor acquires such rights or power.

(v)            We call to your attention the fact that the perfection of a security interest in “proceeds” (as defined in the New York UCC) of collateral is governed and restricted by Section 9-315 of the New York UCC.

(vi)           We have assumed that the exact legal name of the Loan Parties are as set forth in the copy of the organizational documents certified by Secretary of State of the State of Delaware, and we have also assumed the accuracy of the other factual information set forth on the Financing Statements.

(vii)          Section 552 of the federal Bankruptcy Code limits the extent to which property acquired by a debtor after the commencement of a case under the federal Bankruptcy Code may be subject to a security interest arising from a security agreement entered into by the debtor before the commencement of such case.
 
 
 

(viii)         We express no opinion with respect to any property subject to a statute, regulation or treaty of the United States whose requirements for a security interest’s obtaining priority over the rights of a lien creditor with respect to the property preempt Section 9-310(a) of the New York UCC.

(ix)            We express no opinion with respect to any goods which are accessions to, or commingled or processed with, other goods to the extent that the security interest is limited by Section 9-335 or 9-336 of the New York UCC.

(x)            We call to your attention that a security interest may not attach or become enforceable or be perfected as to contracts, licenses, permits, equity interests or other property which are not assignable under applicable law, or are subject to consent requirements or contractual or other prohibitions or restrictions on assignment, except to the extent that any such prohibitions, restrictions or consent requirements may be rendered ineffective to prevent the attachment of the security interest pursuant to Sections 9-406, 9-407, 9-408 or 9-409 of the New York UCC, as applicable, and we note that the extent of any security interest created in reliance on such UCC provisions may be limited.  In addition, we call to your attention that your rights under the Loan Documents as secured parties may be subject to the provisions of the organizational and governing documents of any entity in which any equity interests (or other rights of equity holders or investors) are pledged and the provisions of the applicable laws under which any such entity is organized.

(xi)            We express no opinion regarding any security interest in any copyrights, patents, trademarks, service marks or other intellectual property, or any license or sublicense thereof or the proceeds of any of the foregoing except to the extent Article 9 of the New York UCC may be applicable to the foregoing and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, we express no opinion as to the effect of any federal laws relating to copyrights, patents, trademarks, service marks or other intellectual property on the opinions expressed herein.  In addition, we call to your attention that any license or sublicense of copyrights, patents, trademarks or other intellectual property may not be assignable unless such license or sublicense affirmatively permits the creation, perfection and enforcement of a security interest therein.

(xii)          We express no opinion with respect to the security interest of the Collateral Agent for the benefit of any Secured Party (other than the Lenders) except to the extent that the Collateral Agent has been duly appointed as agent for such persons.

(xiii)         We call to your attention that the issuers of certain of the Pledged Securities are organized under the laws of Canada, England and Wales or Luxembourg, and we express no opinion as to the effect of the laws of Canada, England and Wales or Luxembourg on the opinions herein stated.  Our opinion with respect to the Pledged Securities is limited to the New York UCC to the extent that the New York UCC may be applicable thereto and we express no opinion as to whether as a comity or otherwise a court may defer to the laws of another jurisdiction.  Additionally, we call to your attention that the laws of the jurisdiction of the issuer of the securities may affect, among other things, whether the security is characterized as a “certificated security” under the New York UCC, the exercise of remedies with respect to such security and the exercise of voting or other rights with respect to such security.
 
 
 

(xiv)         We call to your attention that in the case of interests in partnerships and limited liability companies such interests are unlikely to be securities unless their terms expressly provide, and continue to provide, that they are securities governed by Article or Division 8 of the Uniform Commercial Code of the relevant jurisdiction.  Our opinion in paragraph 7 with respect to the Pledged Securities is limited to those partnership interests and limited liability company interests which are, and continue to be, certificated securities.

With your consent, we have assumed (a) that the Loan Documents have been duly authorized, executed and delivered by the parties thereto other than the Loan Parties, (b) that the Loan Documents constitute legally valid and binding obligations of the parties thereto other than the Loan Parties, enforceable against each of them in accordance with their respective terms, and (c) that the status of the Loan Documents as legally valid and binding obligations of the parties is not affected by any (i) breaches of, or defaults under, agreements or instruments, (ii) violations of statutes, rules, regulations or court or governmental orders, or (iii) failures to obtain required consents, approvals or authorizations from, or make required registrations, declarations or filings with, governmental authorities, provided that we make no such assumption to the extent we have opined as to such matters with respect to the Loan Parties herein.
 
 
 
 

EXHIBIT B-2

Form of Opinion

 
[FORM OF OPINION OF FASKEN MARTINEAU DUMOULIN LLP]

1.                             Opinions

Based and relying on the foregoing, and subject to the qualifications, limitations and restrictions hereinafter expressed, we are of the opinion that:

1.             The Canadian LP was formed and is validly existing under the laws of Ontario.

2.             The Canadian LP has the power and capacity under the LP Agreement to enter into, deliver and perform its obligations under the LP Documents and to carry on its business.

3.             The execution and delivery of the LP Documents by the GP on behalf of the Canadian LP and the performance of its obligations thereunder and the consummation of the transactions contemplated by the LP Documents have been duly authorized by all necessary partnership action on the part of the Canadian LP.

4.             The LP Documents have been duly executed by the GP on behalf of the Canadian LP and, to the extent that delivery of LP Documents is governed by the laws of the Province of Ontario, delivered by the GP on behalf of the Canadian LP.

5.             The Amended Canadian GSA is a legal, valid and binding obligation of the Canadian LP and of the GP, enforceable against each of the GP and the Canadian LP, in accordance with their respective terms.

6.

 
(a)
The Amended Canadian GSA is a legal, valid and binding obligation of each other Compass Entity which is a party to it, enforceable against such Compass Entity in accordance with its terms.

 
(b)
The Debenture Pledge Amending Agreement is a legal, valid and binding obligation of Sifto enforceable against Sifto in accordance with its terms.  The Debenture Pledge Amending Agreement has not affected the enforceability of the Debenture Pledge, except in accordance with the terms of the Debenture Pledge Amending Agreement.

7.            The execution and delivery of

 
(i)
each LP Document by the Canadian LP and the performance by the Canadian LP of its obligations thereunder;

 
(ii)
GSA Amendment No. 3 by each Compass Entity which is a party thereto and the performance by such Compass Entity of its obligations thereunder;

 
(iii)
the Security Agreement Supplement by CMI and the performance of its obligations thereunder; and

 
 
 

 
(iv)
the Amended and Restated Security Agreement Supplement by NASC and the performance of its obligations thereunder,

do not constitute or result in a violation or breach of or a default under (a) the LP Agreement or such Document, or (b) any law, rule or regulation having the force of law in the Province of Ontario.

8.             No authorization, consent or approval of, or filing, registration, qualification or recording with, any governmental entity having jurisdiction in the Province of Ontario is required in connection with the execution and delivery of:

 
(a)
the LP Documents or the performance by the Canadian LP of its obligations thereunder;

 
(b)
GSA Amendment No. 3 or the performance by each Compass Entity which is a party thereto of its obligations thereunder;

 
(c)
the Security Agreement Supplement by CMI and the performance of its obligations thereunder; or

 
(d)
the Amended and Restated Security Agreement Supplement by NASC and the performance of its obligations thereunder.

9.             No stamp tax, registration, documentary or other similar tax, duty, levy or fee is payable under the laws of the Province of Ontario or the federal laws of Canada applicable therein in connection with the execution and delivery of:

 
(a)
the LP Documents or the performance by the Canadian LP of its obligations thereunder;

 
(b)
GSA Amendment No. 3 or the performance by each Compass Entity which is a party thereto of its obligations thereunder;

 
(c)
the Security Agreement Supplement by CMI and the performance of its obligations thereunder;

 
(d)
the Amended and Restated Security Agreement Supplement by NASC and the performance of its obligations thereunder; or

 
(e)
the exercise by the Collateral Agent of any of its rights and remedies thereunder.

10.            To the extent that the OPPSA applies to the security interests created by the Amended Canadian GSA,

 
(a)
The Amended Canadian GSA creates valid security interests in favour of the Collateral Agent in the personal property described therein to which the OPPSA applies and in which a security interest may be granted under the OPPSA (the “Ontario Personal Property Collateral”) in which the Compass Entity party thereto now has rights which secures the payment and performance of the obligations described therein as being secured thereby.  The Amended Canadian GSA is sufficient to create valid security interests in favour of the Collateral Agent in Ontario Personal Property Collateral in which the Compass Entity party thereto hereafter acquires rights when those rights are acquired to secure payment and performance of the obligations described therein as being secured thereby.  Registration has been made in all public offices provided for under Ontario Law where such registration is necessary to preserve, protect or perfect the security interests created in favour of the Collateral Agent in the Ontario Personal Property Collateral under the Amended Canadian GSA and the Security Agreement Supplement; and

 
 
 

 
(b)
The security interest created in favour of the Collateral Agent under the Amended and Restated Security Agreement Supplement in the CMI Pledged Shares has been perfected by control by the Collateral Agent and accordingly has priority over any other security interest (to which the OPPSA applies) of any other secured party that does not have control of the CMI Pledged Shares.  If the Collateral Agent had no notice of any adverse claim at the time of obtaining control of the CMI Pledged Shares, the Collateral Agent acquired its security interest in the CMI Pledged Shares free of any adverse claim.

11.            In the event that the Shares Mortgage is sought to be enforced against the Canadian LP, in any action or proceeding in the Province of Ontario in accordance with the laws applicable thereto as chosen by the parties, namely the laws of England, (“English Law”) a court of competent jurisdiction in the Province of Ontario (an “Ontario Court”) would recognize such choice of laws as a valid choice of law to govern the Shares Mortgage and would apply English Law to all issues that an Ontario Court characterized as substantive under the conflict of laws’ rules of the laws of the Province of Ontario, assuming that:

(a)
such choice of law is legal under English Law;

(b)
such choice of law was made bona fide (without limiting the foregoing, such choice of law was not made for the purpose of avoiding the mandatory laws of any other jurisdiction);

(c)
there is no reason for avoiding such choice of law on the grounds of public policy in the Province of Ontario as determined by an Ontario Court;

(d)
English Law is not an assertion of sovereign power of a political nature by the England, such as laws of a penal or taxation nature or laws of extra-territorial application;

(e)
English Law was specifically pleaded and proved as a question of fact before the Ontario Court;

An Ontario Court will apply provisions of Ontario law which have overriding effect and will not enforce the performance of any obligation that is illegal under the laws of any jurisdiction in which the obligation is to be performed.   An Ontario Court will also apply the laws of the Province of Ontario to those issues that the Ontario Court characterizes as procedural or administrative under the conflicts of laws’ rules of the laws of the Province of Ontario.  No opinion is expressed as to whether remedies available under English Law would be available from an Ontario Court.
 
 
 

12.            Pursuant to the convention between Canada and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland providing for the reciprocal enforcement of judgments (the “Enforcement Convention”), any subsisting in personam judgment of an English court (an “English Judgment”) ordering the payment of a fixed sum of money obtained by the Collateral Agent under the Shares Mortgage in an action before the English court against the Canadian LP under the Shares Mortgage may be registered at any time up to six years from its date in the Federal Court of Canada or in an Ontario Court and shall, for purposes of enforcement, be conclusive and of the same force and effect as if it had been a judgment originally given in the Federal Court of Canada or that Ontario Court with effect from the date of registration thereof.  The Enforcement Convention contains certain exceptions and limitations.  Notwithstanding the Enforcement Convention, the Attorney General of Canada pursuant to the Foreign Extraterritorial Measures Act (Canada), the Competition Tribunal pursuant to the Competition Act (Canada) and the Governor-in-Council pursuant to the United Nations Act (Canada) or the Special Economic Measures Act (Canada) may make certain orders prohibiting enforcement of foreign judgments, including any English Judgment.

2.                             Qualifications

The opinions expressed above are subject to the following qualifications:

 
(a)
the enforceability of a Document may be limited by bankruptcy, winding-up, insolvency, arrangement, fraudulent preference and conveyance, assignment and preference and other similar laws of general application affecting the enforcement of creditor’s rights;

 
(b)
a court may exercise discretion in the granting of equitable remedies such as specific performance and injunction;

 
(c)
the enforceability of a Document may be limited by general principles of law and equity relating to the conduct of the Collateral Agent or the Lenders prior to execution of, or in the administration or performance of such Document including, without limitation, (i) undue influence, unconscionability, duress, misrepresentation and deceit, (ii) estoppel and waiver, (iii) laches and (iv) reasonableness and good faith in the exercise of discretionary powers;

 
(d)
the discretion that a court may reserve to itself to decline to hear an action if it is not the proper forum to hear the action or if concurrent proceedings are being brought elsewhere;

 
(e)
we express no opinion as to the enforceability of any provision of the Documents which purports to limit jurisdiction of proceedings exclusively to a Foreign Court;

 
(f)
our opinions in paragraphs 7 and 8 does not extend to (i) any agreement that the Canadian LP may have entered into or with, or with any decision, order or award made by, any governmental body, court, tribunal or similar entity of the Province of Ontario or of Canada, or (ii) any necessary consent, licence, approval, acknowledgement, order or exemption from, registration or filing with or notice to any governmental department or agency or regulatory body or authority required under Ontario Law in order for the Canadian LP to carry on its business;

 
 
 

 
(g)
no opinion is expressed in this opinion letter on whether the Collateral Agent or any Lender has complied or is complying with Section 510 of the Bank Act (Canada) in connection with the origination and negotiation of the Documents or the transactions contemplated thereby or on the effect non-compliance with Section 510 would have on the legality, validity, binding effect or enforceability of the Documents.  For the purposes of this opinion letter, however, we have, with your permission, assumed the Collateral Agent and each such Lender has complied and is complying with Section 510;

 
(h)
provisions in a Document permitting service of legal process by posting or transmission of copies thereof in accordance with the notice clause of such Document may not be recognized as good service on the Canadian LP by an Ontario Court;

 
(i)
no opinion is expressed on the validity of any provision purporting to waive trial by jury;

 
(j)
no opinion is expressed in this opinion letter as to any of those matters which we have assumed for the purposes of rendering the opinions expressed herein;

 
(k)
without limiting the generality of paragraph 10 above, with respect to the security interests in the Collateral created under the Amended Canadian GSA:

 
(i)
acceleration, enforcement and realization under the Amended Canadian GSA may be limited or constrained by the PPSA;

 
(ii)
a security interest in instruments, securities, chattel paper and negotiable documents of title may be perfected by registration but will be defeated by certain claimants obtaining possession of such property in the circumstances described in the PPSA or the Bills of Exchange Act (Canada), as applicable;

 
(iii)
a security interest in goods will be defeated by certain claimants to whom a Compass Entity sells or leases those goods in the ordinary course of business in the circumstances described in the PPSA;

 
(iv)
a security interest perfected by registration of a financing statement under the PPSA will only remain perfected by such registration for its specified registration period unless renewed before the expiry of such period by the filing of a financing change statement or Form 3C properly completed in the manner prescribed under the PPSA;

 
 
 

 
(v)
changes in the corporate name of a Compass Entity, the adoption of a French or combined English/French form of the name of a Compass Entity or transfer by a Compass Entity to any third party of any of its property subject to the security  interests created in favour of the Collateral Agent would require timely registration of a financing change statement properly completed in the manner prescribed under the PPSA to preserve the priority and perfection of the security  interests therein;

 
(vi)
any security interest expressed to be created under the Amended Canadian GSA in any Collateral acquired by a Compass Entity after the execution and delivery thereof will not attach to such Collateral (and will not be enforceable against third parties or perfected) until the such Compass Entity acquires rights in such Collateral;

 
(vii)
no opinion is expressed in this opinion letter with respect to any security interest in Collateral that is transformed in such a way that it is not identifiable or traceable or in any proceeds of Collateral that are not identifiable or traceable; and

 
(viii)
although the Security Agreement Supplement and the related Financing Statement may by its respective terms extend to motor vehicles (which term is broadly defined in the PPSA), no detailed description of any motor vehicle subject to the Security Agreement Supplement was set out in the Financing Statement and thus the security interests in such motor vehicles are subject to the rights of certain claimants in the circumstances described in the PPSA;

 
(l)
the enforceability of a Document is subject to the Limitations Act, 2002 (Ontario), which provides that a limitation period under that Act applies despite any agreement to vary or exclude it, and we express no opinion whether an Ontario Court may find any provision of any Document to be unenforceable as an attempt to vary or exclude a limitation period under that Act;

 
(m)
the liability of NASC Nova Scotia Company as limited partner of the Canadian LP under the LP Documents is limited by the terms of the LP Agreement and the Limited Partnerships Act (Ontario)

 
(n)
the Currency Act (Canada) precludes a court in Canada from giving judgment in any currency other than Canadian currency, and we express no opinion as to the rate of exchange at which the conversion to Canadian currency of any amounts owing by a Compass Entity will he made for the purpose of any judgment;

 
(o)
a court may decline to accept the factual and legal determinations of a party notwithstanding that a contract or instrument provides that the determinations of that party shall be conclusive;

 
 
 

 
(p)
no opinion is given as to the enforceability of any term providing for the severance of illegal or unenforceable provisions from the remaining provisions of an agreement;

 
(q)
the recoverability of costs and expenses may be limited to those a court considers to be reasonably incurred, and the costs and expenses incidental to all court proceedings are in the discretion of the court and the court has the discretion to determine by whom and to what extent these costs shall be paid;

 
(r)
the Collateral Agent may be required to give a Compass Entity a reasonable time to pay following a demand for payment prior to taking any action to enforce its right of payment or before exercising any of the rights and remedies expressed to be exercisable by the Collateral Agent in a Security Document;

 
(s)
we express no opinion as to the enforceability of any provision that states that modifications, amendments or waivers are not binding unless in writing;

 
(t)
we express no opinion as to the enforceability of any provision exculpating any party from liability in respect of acts or omissions that may be illegal, fraudulent or involve wilful misconduct;

 
(u)
any provision that provides for interest to be paid at a higher rate after than before default, that provides for a forfeiture of a deposit or any other property or that provides for a particular calculation of damages upon breach may not be enforceable if it is interpreted by a court to be a penalty or if the court determines that relief from forfeiture is appropriate;

 
(v)
the PPSA requires that the rights of secured parties be exercised and discharged in good faith and in a commercially reasonable manner;

 
(w)
we express no opinion as to (i) the title of any Compass Entity to any property or any rights in such property, (ii)  the validity, perfection, rank or priority of any mortgage charge or security interest created by the Amended Debenture Pledge, or (iii) the rank or priority of any mortgage charge or security interest created by the Amended Canadian GSA;

 
(x)
the PPSA imposes certain obligations on secured creditors which cannot be varied by contract.  The PPSA may also affect the enforcement of certain rights and remedies under the Security Documents, to the extent that these rights and remedies are inconsistent with or contrary to the PPSA;

 
(y)
we express no opinion as to whether a security interest may be created in permits, quotas, licences or other property which, is neither personal property nor an interest in land;

 
(z)
we have not registered any of GSA Amendment No. 3 or the Debenture Pledge Amending Agreement or notice thereof under the PPSA or in any land registry office or under any land registry statutes;

 
 
 

 
(aa)
we express no opinion as to the creation of any security interest in:

 
(i)
property consisting of a receivable, licence, approval, privilege, franchise, permit, lease or agreement (collectively, “Special Property”) to the extent that the terms of the Special Property or any applicable law prohibit the assignment or require, as a condition of assignability, a consent, approval or other authorization or registration which has not been made or given;

 
(ii)
federal Crown debts to the extent the Financial Administration Act (Canada) has not been complied with; and

 
(iii)
any transfer of an interest or claim in or under any policy of insurance or contract of annuity other than in respect of the transfer of a right to money or other value payable under the policy of insurance as indemnity or compensation for loss of, or damage to, the Collateral;

 
(bb)
the provisions for the payment of interest in a Security Document may not be enforceable if those provisions provide for the receipt of interest at a “criminal rate” within the meaning of section 347 of the Criminal Code (Canada);

 
(cc)
a receiver, manager or receiver-manager appointed pursuant to any of the Security Documents may, for certain purposes, be treated as agent for the Collateral Agent and not solely as agent for the applicable Compass Entity notwithstanding any provision in the Security Documents to the contrary;

 
(dd)
a security interest, mortgage or charge in (i) any goods purchased under any licence, (ii) an approval, privilege, quota, franchise, permit or lease, (iii) an instrument, contract, account or agreement, (iv) investment property or (v) property subject to any of the Canada Shipping Act (Canada), the Copyright Act (Canada), the Integrated Circuits Topography Act (Canada), the Industrial Designs Act (Canada), the Patent Act (Canada), the Plant Breeders’ Rights Act (Canada), the Canada Transportation Act (Canada), the Trade-marks Act (Canada), the Financial Administration Act (Canada), the Land Titles Act (Ontario), the Registry Act (Ontario), the Railways Act (Ontario) (the “Special Property Statutes”) may not be perfected, valid, binding or enforceable because of the nature or terms of such property, or to the extent the nature or terms of such property or any statute or regulation require a consent, approval, acknowledgment, notice or other authorization or registration which has not been given or made;

 
(ee)
no opinion is expressed in this opinion letter as to the validity, effect or enforceability under any of the Special Property Statutes of any security interest, mortgage or charge  expressed to be created in favour of the Collateral Agent under any Security Document in any real or personal property of a Compass Entity or (ii) any required registration, filing, recording or notice under any of the Special Property Statutes in respect of such security interest in any personal property subject to the Special Property Statutes;

 
 
 

 
(ff)
the recoverability of costs and expenses may be limited to those a court considers to be reasonably incurred, and the costs and expenses incidental to all court proceedings are in the discretion of the court and the court has the discretion to determine by whom and to what extent these costs shall be paid;

 
(gg)
we have not conducted searches or made inquiries in respect of any statutory liens or deemed trusts which may arise against the property of any Compass Entity pursuant to the laws of the Province of Ontario or the Province of British Columbia or the federal laws of Canada applicable therein except for searches of notices of intention to give security under the Bank Act (Canada) and the PPSAs;

 
(hh)
under the Courts of Justice Act (Ontario) interest after judgment may be limited to a rate which is less than a rate specified in any Document;

 
(ii)
a certificate, determination, notification or opinion of the Collateral Agent as to any matter provided for in any Document may be held by an Ontario Court not to be conclusive if it can be shown to have an unreasonable or arbitrary basis or in the event of manifest error;

 
(jj)
a waiver or release of or limitation on rights or remedies available to any Compass Entity in respect of future actions or omissions of the Collateral Agent, or any agent or receiver and manager appointed by or on the application of the Collateral Agent, may not be enforced by an Ontario Court;

 
(kk)
no opinion is expressed as to the enforceability of any provision in any Document which suggests that modifications, amendments or waivers that are not in writing will not be effective, which purports to prevent the exercise of a right of set-off, a defence by counterclaim or other rights or which provides that remedies may be exercised cumulatively;

 
(ll)
our opinions in paragraphs 7 and 8 only address statutes and regulations of general application in the Province of Ontario and do not address or extend to (i) any necessary authorization, permit consent, license, approval, acknowledgment, order or exemption from, registration or filing with, or notice to, any government department or agency or any regulatory body or authority required by any Compass Entity under Ontario Law in order to carry on its particular business, or (ii) any agreement any Compass Entity may have entered into with, or any decision, order or award made by, any government department or agency or any regulatory body or authority of the Province of Ontario or of Canada;

 
(mm)
no opinion is expressed in this opinion letter on any security interest expressed to be created in property, or expressed to be creating an interest in property, to which the OPPSA does not apply in accordance with the provisions thereof, or the validity of which is not governed by the OPPSA in accordance with sections 5 to 8.1 of the OPPSA;

 
(nn)
no opinion is expressed in this opinion letter as to whether it may be necessary in connection with the enforcement of any Document for the Collateral Agent or any other persons proposing to acquire, own or operate all or any part of the property secured thereunder to give any notice or obtain or effect any licence, franchise, permit, consent, approval, registration or other authorization or exemption in connection therewith;

 
 
 

 
(oo)
our opinions in paragraph 10 do not address any of the following matters:

 
(i)
any required registration, filing, recording or notice in respect of any fixtures, goods that may become fixtures, crops, minerals or hydrocarbons to be extracted, or timber to be cut; or

 
(ii)
any required caution filing or other registration, filing, recording or notice which may be required in certain circumstances where goods are intended to be brought or are brought into Ontario;

 
(pp)
no opinion is expressed on the validity, effect or enforceability of any waiver of jury trial contained in any Document;

 
(qq)
no opinion is expressed on the validity or effect of any service of process served in accordance with the provisions of any Document if such service is not made in compliance with the Rules of Civil Procedure;

 
(rr)
no opinion is expressed in this opinion letter on the validity, effect or perfection of any mortgage, charge or security interest in real property, or any personal property that is or becomes a fixture or any building materials that are or become affixed to real property; and

 
(ss)
no opinion is expressed in this opinion letter on the submission by the Canadian LP to the exclusive jurisdiction of an English Court contained in Section 32 of the Shares Mortgage.
 
 
 
 

EXHIBIT B-3

Form of Opinion

 
[FORM OF OPINION OF ENGLISH COUNSEL]

Our opinions are based upon the following assumptions:

1. 
the genuineness of all signatures, stamps and seals on the Documents;

2.
the conformity to the originals of all documents supplied to us as certified, photostatic or faxed copies and the authenticity of the originals of such documents;

3.
that the Documents are complete, accurate and up to date and have not been amended or rescinded and are in full force and effect;

4.
that each party, other than the English Subsidiaries, is duly organised, validly existing and in good standing (where such concept is legally relevant) under the laws of its jurisdiction of incorporation;

5.
the capacity, power and authority of each of the parties to the Documents, other than the English Subsidiaries, to execute, deliver and perform its obligations and, as appropriate, grant the security interests created thereunder and the due execution and delivery by each party thereto, other than the English Subsidiaries, of the Documents;

6.
the due compliance by all parties with all matters under any law other than that of England (including, without limitation, the obtaining of necessary consents, licences, approvals and authorisations and the making of necessary filings, lodgements, registrations and notifications and the payment of stamp duties and other documentary charges and taxes) as may relate to the Documents, the parties thereto, the persons affected thereby and the transactions contemplated thereby;

7.
that all obligations under the Documents are valid, legally binding upon and enforceable against the parties thereto as a matter of all relevant laws other than the laws of England;

8.
the absence of mutual mistake of fact or any other arrangements, understandings or course of conduct or prior dealings modifying or superseding any of the terms of the Documents, or that would result in the inclusion of additional terms therein, and that the parties have acted in accordance with the terms of such agreements and documents;

9.
that the choice of law provisions governing each of the Documents were made for bona fide purposes and are valid and binding under all relevant laws other than the laws of England;

10.
that none of the opinions expressed below would be affected by any law or public policy of any jurisdiction other than England;

11.
that all the terms and conditions of the Documents will be observed and performed by all the parties thereto;

12.
that the Security Agent has complied with the Financial Services & Markets Act 2000 (and all subordinate and secondary legislation) in relation to any security taken over shares, securities or other investments (as defined in the Financial Services & Markets Act 2000);

 
 
 

13.
that the execution and delivery of the Documents to which they are a party by each of the English Subsidiaries and the exercise by each of them of their rights and the performance by each of them of their obligations thereunder is a proper use of their powers and will sufficiently benefit and is in the interests of that English Subsidiary and such documents have been entered by all parties thereto in good faith on arm’s length commercial terms for the purposes of carrying on their respective businesses;

14.
that the information revealed by the searches conducted by Sevenside Company Services on our behalf on 10 September 2010 (or 23 September 2010 in the case of Compass Minerals (Europe) Limited) (as updated by our online review on 29 September 2010) of the public records of each of the English Subsidiaries kept at the Companies Registration Office was, in each case, accurate in all respects and has not been altered since the time of such search;

15.
the English Subsidiaries have filed at the Companies Registry all documents they are required to file;

16.
that the information revealed by our oral enquiries in respect of each of the English Subsidiaries made on 29 September 2010 at the Central Registry of Winding Up Petitions at the Royal Courts of Justice, London was accurate in all respects and, in each case, has not since the time of our enquiry been altered (such searches are collectively referred to hereinafter as the “Winding Up Searches”),

17.
the accuracy and completeness of all representations relating to matters of fact (but not law) contained in the Documents;

18.
that the resolutions set out in the board minutes of each of the English Subsidiaries (as referred to in paragraph (f) above) were properly passed at duly convened meetings of duly appointed directors and that those meetings remained quorate throughout, have not been amended, superseded or rescinded and are in full force and effect, and that any provisions contained in the Companies Act 2006  or the Articles of Association of each such English Subsidiary relating to the declaration of directors’ interests or the power of interested directors to vote were duly observed;

19.
that the submission to the jurisdiction of the English courts by each of the parties to the Documents (other than the English Subsidiaries) is valid, legally binding and enforceable as a matter of all relevant laws;

20.
that no fraud, bad faith, coercion, undue influence or duress exists or was exerted and no misrepresentation was made on the part of any of the parties to the Documents, their employees, agents and advisers; and

 
 
 

21.
none of the English Subsidiaries is unable to pay its debts within the meaning of section 123 of the Insolvency Act 1986 at the time of execution of the Documents to which it is a party and will not, as a consequence of executing such Documents to which it is a party, be unable to pay its debts within the meaning of that section.

22.
no English Subsidiary has:

a.             passed a voluntary winding-up resolution or a resolution to appoint a liquidator or administrator and no step has been taken by its directors in relation to obtaining a moratorium or making proposals for a voluntary arrangement under part 1 of the Insolvency Act 1986;

b.             no petition has been presented, application made or notice given by any person, and no order has been made by any court, for its winding up, dissolution or administration;

c.             no receiver, administrative receiver, administrator or similar officer has been appointed in relation to it or any of its assets or revenues;

d.             no application has been made to the Registrar of Companies for its striking off nor have any steps been taken by the Registrar of Companies in relation thereto;

in each case which was not revealed by the Company Search or the Winding-up Searches;

Subject to the foregoing and the other matters set forth herein, it is our opinion that, as of the date hereof:

(a)
Status: Each of the English Subsidiaries is duly incorporated and existing under the laws of England and:

 
(i)
the Company Searches revealed no orders or resolutions for the winding up of any of the English Subsidiaries and no notices of appointment in respect of any of the English Subsidiaries of a liquidator, receiver, administrative receiver or administrator; and

 
(ii)
the Winding Up Searches indicated that no petition for the winding up of any of the English Subsidiaries has been presented.

(b)
Power and Authority: Each of the English Subsidiaries has all requisite corporate power to enter into, deliver and perform its obligations under the Documents to which it is a party and has taken all necessary corporate action to authorise the entry into, delivery and performance of its obligations under such Documents.

(c)
Non-conflict: The entry into, delivery and performance by each of the English Subsidiaries of its obligations under the Documents to which it is a party does not violate any provision of its Memorandum and Articles of Association.

 
 
 

The opinions set forth above are subject to the following reservations:

(1)
we express no opinion on matters of fact;

(2)
we express no opinion as to:

 
(i)
the title of any of the English Subsidiaries to any Security Asset;

 
(ii)
the priority of any security created or purported to be created pursuant to the Security Documents;

 
(iii)
the nature of the security created by the Security Documents;

 
(iv)
the value of any of the assets or rights which are expressed to be charged, assigned or otherwise encumbered under the Security Documents;

 
(v)
the marketability of, or rights of enforcement over, any Security Asset; or

 
(vi)
whether any trust contained in any Document is a Security interest;

(3)
we express no opinion as to whether any of the Security Documents are in a form appropriate to create security interests in the Security Assets in respect of which they purport to create security;

(4)
we express no opinion as to whether the obligations expressed to be assumed by each of the English Subsidiaries in the Security Documents to which they are to be a party will constitute legal or valid or binding or enforceable  obligations on them;

(5)
we express no opinion as to whether the entry into, delivery and performance by, each of the English Subsidiaries of its obligations under the Documents to which it is a party does not violate any provision of any existing English law applicable to them;

(6)
we express no opinion as to whether the submission by each of the English Subsidiaries to the jurisdiction of the English courts in respect of disputes or other actions arising in connection with the Security Documents to which they are a party is enforceable as a matter of English law;

(7)
we express no opinion as to whether the choice of English law as the governing law of each of the Security Documents is a valid choice of law as a matter of English law or whether such choice of law will be recognised, upheld and applied by the courts of England as a valid choice of law in any action or proceeding brought before such court in respect of any Security Document;

(8)
we express no opinion with regard to taxation matters, including without limit, stamp duty or stamp duty reserve tax;

(9)
we express no opinion as to whether a Lender or Agent is required to be domiciled in the United Kingdom to exercise any rights in connection with the Security Documents or whether the execution, delivery or performance or enforcement of the Documents affects the residence or domicile of the Agents or the Lenders;

 
 
 

(10)
we express no opinion as to whether it is necessary or advisable under the laws of England that the Documents be filed, registered, enrolled or recorded with or executed or notarised or subjected to any other formality before, any court or governmental authority in England or that any stamp, documentary registration or similar taxes, fees or charges be paid in the United Kingdom to ensure the legality, validity or the enforceability or admissibility into evidence of the Documents;

(11)
the Company Searches are not capable of revealing conclusively whether or not:

 
(i)
a winding up order has been made or a resolution passed for the winding up of a company;

 
(ii)
an administration order has been made; or

 
(iii)
a receiver, administrative receiver, administrator or liquidator has been appointed,

since notice of these matters may not be filed with the Registrar of Companies immediately and, when filed, may not be entered on the public database or recorded in the public records of the relevant company immediately.  In addition, the Company Searches are not capable of revealing, prior to the making of the relevant order, whether or not a winding up petition or a petition for an administration order has been presented;

(12)
the Winding Up Searches relate only to compulsory winding up and are not capable of revealing conclusively whether or not a winding up petition in respect of a compulsory winding up has been presented, since details of the petition may not have been entered on the records of the Central Registry of Winding Up Petitions immediately or, in the case of petition presented to a County Court, may not have been notified to the Central Registry of Winding Up Petitions and entered on such records at all, and the response to an enquiry only relates to the period of approximately four years prior to the date on which the enquiry was made;

(13)
we express no opinion as to any right or obligation which any of the documents purports to confer or impose upon any person which is not a party thereto;

(14)
under English law, any obligation to pay additional interest in circumstances of breach or default may be held to be unenforceable on the ground that it is a penalty and thus void; and

(15)
any determination, calculation or certificate made or given pursuant to the provisions of any Document which provides for such determination, calculation or certificate to be final, conclusive and binding may not be so if the same are made fraudulently, incorrectly, arbitrarily or without good faith and such provision will not necessarily prevent judicial enquiry into the merits of the case at the request of any party to the Documents (as the case may be).
 
 
 
 

EXHIBIT B-4

Form of Opinion

 
[FORM OF OPINION OF ALLEN & OVERY LUXEMBOURG]

1.
Based upon, and subject to, the assumptions made above and the qualifications set out below and subject to any matters not disclosed to us, we are of the opinion that, under the laws of Luxembourg in effect, and as construed and applied by the Luxembourg courts, on the date hereof:

1.1
Status

Each of the Companies is a private limited liability company (société à responsabilité limitée) formed for an unlimited duration and legally existing under the laws of Luxembourg.

1.2
Power and authority

Each of the Companies has the corporate power and authority to enter into and perform the Agreements and has taken all necessary corporate actions to authorise the execution of the Agreements.

1.3
Execution

The Agreements have been duly executed by Mr Rodney L. Underdown on behalf of each of the Companies, in conformity with the Resolutions.

1.4
Non-conflict

The execution and performance by the Companies, and the compliance with the terms, of the Agreements do not violate any applicable law of Luxembourg relating to private limited liability companies generally or the Articles.

2.
The above opinions are subject to the following qualifications:

2.1
The rights and obligations of the Companies may be affected or limited by, the provisions of any applicable bankruptcy (faillite), insolvency, liquidation, reprieve from payment (sursis de paiement), controlled management (gestion contrôlée), composition with creditors (concordat préventif de faillite), reorganisation proceedings or similar Luxembourg or foreign law proceedings or regimes affecting the rights of creditors generally.

2.2
A search at the Register is not capable of conclusively revealing whether a (and the Certificates do not constitute conclusive evidence that no) winding-up resolution or petition, or an order adjudicating or declaring a, or a petition or filing for, bankruptcy or reprieve from payment (sursis de paiement), controlled management (gestion contrôlée), composition with creditors (concordat préventif de faillite) or judicial liquidation or similar action has been adopted or made.

 
 
 

2.3
The corporate documents of, and relevant court orders affecting, a Luxembourg company (including, but not limited to, the notice of a winding-up order or resolution, notice of the appointment of a receiver or similar officer) may not be held at the Register immediately and there is generally a delay in the relevant document appearing on the files regarding the company concerned. Furthermore, it cannot be ruled out that the required filing of documents has not occurred or that documents filed with the Register may have been mislaid or lost. In accordance with Luxembourg company law, changes or amendments to corporate documents to be filed at the Register will be effective (opposable) vis-à-vis third parties only as of the day of their publication in the Luxembourg official gazette (Mémorial C, Recueil des Sociétés et Associations) (the Official Gazette) unless the company proves that the relevant third parties had prior knowledge thereof.

2.4
We express no tax opinion whatsoever in respect of the Companies or the tax consequences of the transactions contemplated by the Agreements. We express no opinion on matters of fact.

2.5
We express no opinion whatsoever on the legal validity and the enforceability of the Agreements.

3.
This legal opinion is as of this date and we undertake no obligation to update it or advise of changes hereafter occurring. We express no opinion as to any matters other than those expressly set forth herein, and no opinion is, or may be, implied or inferred herefrom.

4.
